title: Will the closing price of Chevron stock be higher on 5 August 2020 than it was on 7 July 2020?
preds: The trend is your friend....usually. And the trend is UP.

Trends over the past few months suggest the stock is fluctuating between low 80s and high 80s to low 90s. As it is currently trending upwards at 86.59, it has not yet reached the peak where is normally inverts and begins creeping downwards.
After a wild few days, it all comes down to the very last day with the stock at $86.49 at close today. $86.36 in after hours trading. A straight 50/50 shot.
Adjust down from previous as over the last year 2 days of positive gains have turned into 3 days 46% of the time.
Sitting at cusp over 86.31, due to positive factory orders report and macro news

Whatever the outcome, must learn to remember that looking at institutional investors here - not value investors, the easy rebound since last week shows. Dividend sapping quarterly result against a very hard long term outlook means is not a value investment - again, have to forget about that and look past basic investment fundamentals when looking at these kind of questions.
It’s a coin toss at this point.

Hard to tell with too much volatility...right now
From $86.31to $86.08 today
Oil climbed as stronger equities offset the return of OPEC+ supply to a market already hit by a pandemic-driven demand slump. Currently at 86.05
Essentially 50-50 from a pure volatility standpoint. Bumping over slightly based on recent movement plus another hair for random chance of moderately positive news.

Hard to tell with too much volatility...right now 
From $86.31to $84.81 today
Re-calculated closing price with volatility same as yesterday. Could go either way.

Regression towards the mean at this level suggests it will continue to tick upward in the coming days. Similar points in recent months have had significant increases on the days following as well, so it is more likely than not to continue trending upward. Whether it reaches the appropriate level is up in the air.

Aug 3 close = 84.81USD up 1% --- WTI at USD/bbl. 40.7 up about the same as Chevron on the day. WTI appears to be climbling modestly
Chevron UP 1% = 85.65
Chevron UP 1% = 86.51 which is greater than the target. 
This call may be right on the bubble depending on how traders feel on Wednesday. I'll sit on the fence and watch the action.

Missed already lowered Q2 expectations, but still committed to dividend and will increase debt loads. 
Ex Div date is mid Aug, so may experience an uptick around Aug 15, though likely to still finish below the 7 July price.
Hard to tell with too much volatility...right now it is $2.3 lower..let's see

Chevron's performance over the past 6 months suggests it is currently trending downward, though daily fluctuations can go in either direction. After falling over $6 in just two days, its price is more volatile than ever, but with only 2 trading periods left, it is more likely to remain relatively flat or even decrease than to surpass the $86.31 mark in the coming days.

Probability based solely on volatility: 32% Close enough that macro/news swings could influence. Probability good news/bad news? Oil demand has been increasing moderately, prompting OPEC to meet new demand. Relative to the massive earnings miss, news over the next few days will probably seem a bit better so 65:35 good, with significant news in general: 10%

This corresponds to a 2.8% increase in three business days. Base rate over the last 10 years: 9.9%
Crowd sits at 27%. Forecast: 12%
Not seeing much driving it back up but could easily drift either way

Bad news out of earnings but not crippling. Could be a bit of an overcorrection and could wander back up; but would need to significant positive news to make it a sure thing, which is extremely unlikely.
Going back to base, fundamentals were always weak.
The failure to pass stimulus, and the spikes in the coronavirus will put downward pressure on the price.
I was too high for too long, so I'll paddle the other way and maybe get a 50/50 chance of being right
CVX is very close to the July 7 price.  Acknowledging that I really don't know what will happen in the next week I'll put the odds close to 50/50.

P_now = 86.37
P_then = 86.31
that's about the same, and there's a 50/50% chance of being higher than its current price, at a first approx.
It's actually exactly at 86.31 right now...
Going up from 45 to 75 here. Will follow the results and revise.
Current closing price is $90.07. Estimates are pointing to no surprises in the quarterly earnings [1]. [1] https://finance.yahoo.com/news/big-oil-q2-earnings-preview-123012635.html
Going with the flow over past several days.
The current price is trending downward, but a regression towards the mean of the last several months suggests the price will likely be slightly higher than the July 7th price on any given day.
As the price of WTI rises so go the majors.
Crowd forecast on companion to the ordinal #1693 shows the majority believes it will be above $83.
While US is in somewhat of a stall other places are ramping up.

Base rate over the last 10 years for a sufficient dip to make this "no" is at 10.3%. Slightly bumping this up, as I expect bad surprises in the quarterly earnings to be slighlty more likely than good ones. => 87% that the price will be higher on 5 August.

Well below the crowd what's slightly nervewracking. Note Noble as a positive but, regardless, outlooks looks grim - quarterly release could put Noble into perspective & bring stocks down towards March/April levels imo,

July 24=90.93USD in a down market. WTI appears stable at 40ish.
July 20 = 85.27USD down 2% in an up market. Assume oil hovers in the $40 range and that demand remains slack for the next 3 weeks.
July 21 = 91.39USD vs the target of 86.31.
July 23 = 90.33USD on a down market day
Now that the crowd is trending up to reasonable territory... I find this a good bet, but not a certainty.
Earnings call in 7 days. Doesn't have to do well, just has to beat expectations - I think it will.

Purchase of Noble energy at a good value for the reserves. https://www.reuters.com/article/us-noble-energy-m-a-deals/chevrons-5-billion-deal-for-noble-ends-deal-drought-sets-price-benchmark-idUSKCN24M1IN
potential issues with Gorgon LNG https://www.upstreamonline.com/safety/unions-call-for-chevron-to-halt-gorgon-production-amid-safety-concerns/2-1-846256
market has priced in expected losses...
CVX is currently above the $86.31 price of 7 July, and with today's acquisition of Noble Energy, investors should have any concerns alleviated as Chevron is driving growth.

July 20 = 85.27USD down 2% in an up market. Assume oil hovers in the $40 range and that demand remains slack for the next 3 weeks.
July 21 = 91.39USD vs the target of 86.31.
July 23 = 90.33USD on a down market day

Despite the stock market's irrational exuberance, oil fundamentals remain poor, and Chevron is likely to post further losses in its earnings release. Add to that the likelihood that Australian regulators will find more problems at Chevron's monumentally expensive Gorgon LNG project, and the possibility that any of the other oil majors will be forced to cut their dividends, and it doesn't portend well for Chevron's stock price.

$86.31 on 7th July; $91.04 on 22nd July.  So needs to be about $5 lower than now It's a martingale so I don't know what will happen between now and 5th August Chevron's published data can be used to show how much their stock varies in a 2 week period, using data from last 12 months. In that year 14% of the time the stock would fall by at least $5 in the following fortnight Given that past doesn't predict future and unforeseen events could occur, I adjust down from 100 - 14 = 86%, to 81%

July 20 = 85.27USD down 2% in an up market. Assume oil hovers in the $40 range and that demand remains slack for the next 3 weeks.
July 21 = 91.39USD vs the target of 86.31.
Looks like Mr. Market has spoken loud and clear.
Citing @Bobbiekar52 and recent news: https://www.forbes.com/sites/davidblackmon/2020/07/20/chevrons-deal-to-buy-noble-energy-attracts-positive-analyst-reviews/#fe1297b2459a Holding fast.

My initial rationale was that with the number of infections leading to hospitalization leading to deaths leading to fear the stock market might be down by then. Of course it also appears the stock market is disconnected from the now and riding on expected future earnings. RV rentals are up. People are out and about. Hmm. More gas use so stock up. Could go either way. In the 50s seems right.
July 20 = 85.27USD down 2% in an up market. Assume oil hovers in the $40 range and that demand remains slack for the next 3 weeks.
With the acquisition of Noble and "toppish" WTI struggling to build on gains above $40, I am reassessing this probability down quite a bit.

Chevron Just bought Noble Energy for $5Bn, looks like a great deal for Chevron on the surface. Usually, the buyers stock drops and the sellers goes up in the short term in these situations. However, I think both stocks will rise in the following weeks due to the deal.
Climbing on the fence on this one.

Short-term stock price projections are only guesses.  If I could predict short-term movements with even a 55% success rate I would be rich.  That said, I'm going to guess that the price will decline modestly from here.  If it increases north of $90 per share I'll switch my bet.
I explained almost The same in another forecast.

I thank @Jayce for his recent analysis. Here's mine: This is basically a coin flip given the short time frame.  The earnings report could be good or bad relative to expectations. Unless there are major negative surpises regarding outlook , I don't think the report will mean much.  Investors in this market have discounted all the bad news up till now, even including medium term expectations. They are looking years out. Otherwise, how explain how the market has held up so well?  I am slightly bullish on Chevron in this time frame now because the market seems to be turning over, with tech retracing but energy holding up. I believe oil will hold at $40 because that's where OPEC wants it. Chevron is well enough positioned in the Permian to do ok at $40.  There are also recent signs of commodity strength elsewhere, particularly in copper. Whether this is due to renewed China growth or inflation, oil will benefit. (Chevron benefits from inflation because all that oil in the ground increases in nominal value.)  I.e., if copper continues to rally over the next couple weeks, this would be bullish for energy.
Checked Chevron upcoming Earning estimate. In minus range. Buy to sell ratio is 1 to 2. Going way lower.

Alright, let's get down to brass tacks.
The crowd is at 17% which I think is silly. First off, let me say that if I knew for certain, I'd have more money than I do now.
So 17% is my ground floor. Chevron has a large footprint and a lot of real estate. Though their market cap has plateaued in recent years, you better believe they have a finger on the pulse of the future and have no plans to go gentle into that good night. At $125, CVX was overpriced and due for a revision, but even pre-C19 it held. Now at $86, it is a steal. The established trading community sees the same writing on the wall as everyone else but who doesn't enjoy a cliffhanger? 
With a P/E of 13.67 and handsome dividend of ~6%, CVX is still the darling of many a boomer nest egg.  Robinhood, Morningstar and Zacks consider CVX a modest "buy" - https://www.zacks.com/stock/research/CVX/stock-style-scores So what does that mean?
Let's say we get the earnings report... ...and it is good: People shout "hooray!" and buy it up. They benefited from people driving more because they are flying less. They beat the 'rona slump. ...and it is bad: People shout "oh no!" and some sell off chunks of shares and the price dips... then the professionals see the dip, and knowing the basis of my previous paragraph buy the dip and enjoy a handsome discount. In both scenarios, I see a plausible rise in share price. Earnings come out 7/31, pre-market (a bold, promising move,) and they handily beat expectations. Almost no outlets I've seen have called CVX a "sell."
Growth is expected, value has been maintained better than their rivals, downstream earnings are consistently strong albeit a smaller footprint. Inflation and shrinking demand pose reasonable risks. If I'm wrong and everything falls apart, then all bets are off.
Am I confident they'll perform well? Yes. Would I bet the farm? No. Is it possible that this question will close on an arbitrary downswing due to bad news? Yes. Does it matter? No.
That said, you could take the exact opposite of everything I said in my rationale and it'd be almost equally plausible. @Balzac thank you for encouraging a deeper dive. I know you agree that the consensus seems off, so I welcome and appreciate any research you dig up. I started decisive as my initial forecast, and I *want* to nudge up further, but I think the highest I can go on this one is 59-63%. I don't know to what degree I'll bounce around that range. This *is* a coin toss, and I realize that any prediction <45% or >55% is based on bias and bravado. Don't be a hero.
I'm starting here, will taper off into nuanced uncertainty later... kinda surprised the crowd is being so conservative. I'll explain why later.

Hope I don't lose my shirt on this random prediction. The crowd is at 15%, which is absurd. Regretting entering the field. This is a coin toss, folks! I'll go as low as 40% since the price is down slightly.
Low demand, results in July will reflect and no clear path in immediate term.
Earnings down, oil especially hard hit due to lower demand, political turmoil; all the trends of which I expect to continue.
Not a great trend over the last month. Short-term oil signs look febrile.

July 9 mid day = 83.52 down 3% on the day. WTI=39.96 slightly off. Petroleum exploration, drilling, production and refining appear to be all under pressure. Well run companies as well as marginal ones feeling the pressure. Covid continues to stymie the best laid plans for returning to normal. Thus demand is off and supply is abundant.
An even shot (with a slightly bearish bias).

Predicting what will happen over the next four weeks is nearly impossible.  Maybe a hedge fund manager will bet heavily one way or the other.  But for someone like me, with very limited knowledge of the oil business, it's close to a coin flip.  I would note that CVX has been in a trading range of about $85-95 for over two months.  It's near the low of that range right now.  So I'll start with a bet of 53%, on the assumption that it will stay inside its trading range.  If it breaks out to the downside I'll flip hard towards NO.
Based on stock history. it may continue swinging slightly.

I think it is more of a beta-question here (30-d beta is around 1.5 towards S&P500), which suggest the stock is very sensitive to respective changes in the index.
Chevron fell by more than 50 per cent in spring 2020 due to the blood bath on the oil market (their business model is long crude oil price by nature and long travel due to downstream products). As stocks in general are currently "ambitiously priced" to say the least considering political markets ahead of US presidential elections and economic reality, the S&P500 is likely to fall over the next month. High beta means Chevron is likely to exaggerate the drop and will fall even more. I guess the stock is going to see 65USD before it can turn better.
Stabilizing crude oil markets and more demand for gas is likely to compensate for some of the recent troubles, and Chevron announced it is going to pay a dividend anyway (cashflows are likely still positive). But things are never going to be the same, easy cakewalk for Big Oil again, since the political will for a substitution of fossile fuels by sustainable energy production and a de-carbonization of the economies and most societies seems real this time.

Without more information isn't 50% appropriate? (If you put over 55% have you bought Chevron stock, and if you put under 40% have you shorted it?) Genuinely keen to hear other's views on this, as will sharpen my own understanding Trends here: https://www.bloomberg.com/quote/CVX:US

The world in some key places like China and Europe are opening up. The US has opened Up but to early and people are not following precautions. More lockdown could follow but that is being resisted. In general with oil cutbacks and increased use in the world Chevron should be higher.
